Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Pilot Project on Interactive Land Use and Climate Predictions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: A Pilot Project on Interactive Land Use and Climate Predictions


Abstract:

In the past land use predictions have been based primarily on population and socioeconomic development scenarios, and have been provided to climate prediction models as an external driver. The role of climate as a major biophysical driver for land use changes has not been adequately considered. Using West Africa as an example, this project will address the overarching question of whether there is a strong need to include land use predictions as an integral component of Earth System Models. The objectives of the project are: (1) to predict future climate and land use considering the interaction between climate and land use; (2) to evaluate the roles of greenhouse gas emissions and land use in driving regional climate changes in West Africa; and (3) to understand the impacts of biophysical and socioeconomic factors on land use changes. Based on a proposed modeling framework that links a cascade of five models, i.e., a regional climate model, a dynamic vegetation model, a crop growth model, an agricultural economics model, and a land use allocation model, the PIs will study the impact of both socio-economic and biophysical factors on human land use. This project will shed insights into whether and to what extent, climate-land use interactions in earth system models influence predictions of future climate and future land use.

The broader impacts of this research are high. Climate change and its adverse impact on food security are a major concern for West African countries and international organizations. Results from this project will provide scientific foundations for food policy and targeted investment in climate change adaptation. In addition, this project will promote teaching and learning in a broader context, as well as increase the participation of underrepresented groups, especially women, in geosciences research.

This grant supports a collaborative effort among three institutions including the University of Connecticut, Loyola Marymount University, and the International Food Policy Research Institute.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using West Africa as an example, the overarching goal of this project is to assess the need for including land use predictions as an integral component of Earth System Models. Specific objectives are: (1) to project future climate and agricultural land use considering the interactions between climate and land use; (2) to evaluate the roles of greenhouse gas emissions and agricultural land use in driving regional climate changes in West Africa; and (3) to understand the impacts of biophysical and socioeconomic factors on land use changes. These objectives were achieved based on a modeling framework that links a cascade of four models, including a regional climate model (RegCM4.3.4-CLM4.5), a crop growth model (DSSAT), an agricultural economics model (IMPACT), and a land use projection model for crops (LandPro_Crop).

Major findings from this project include: (1) Including land use-climate interactions in the regional climate system model causes significant differences in future projections for both climate and land use; (2) Over most of West Africa, the projected future land use causes a dry signal, which enhances the impact of GHG-induced future precipitation changes; (3) The relative importance of climate and socioeconomic factors as land use drivers is highly region dependent, with land use change dominated by climate in the western portion and by socioeconomic development elsewhere in West Africa; and 4) Science-informed decision making in land use has the potential to significantly reduce the expansion of agricultural land while still meeting the demand for food, which has significant implications for national land use policy making.

In addition to improved scientific understanding, the project led to two major models that can be (and have been) used by the broad research community: (1) a coupled regional climate system model RegCM-CLM-CN-DV that has been adopted by multiple groups; and (2) a cropland projection model LandPro_Crop that produces a grid-based distribution of total cropland coverage (which satisfies the need of climate models) as well as coverage of individual crops (which satisfies the need of food security planning and land use policy making).

Research in this project led to 17 journal articles (15 published/accepted and 2 submitted), a book chapter, and 8 conference presentations including two invited talks, and contributed materials to class projects for graduate students and to presentations used in the PI’s outreach activities. The LMU portion of the project has supported two postdoctoral associates, one of which is now a senior scientist at West African Science Service Center on Climate Change and Adapted Landuse and the other an assistant professor at the Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research.
